t: Habakkuk 1
The*p oracle that Habakkuk the prophet saw.
Habakkuk’s Complaint
O*pn Lord,*s how long shall I cry for help, and*ld you will not hear? Or*ln cry to you “Violence!” and*ld you will not save?
Why*ln do you make me see iniquity, and*ld why do you idly look at wrong? Destruction*ln and violence are before me; strife*ld and contention arise.
So*ln the law is paralyzed, and*ld justice never goes forth. For*ln the wicked surround the righteous; so*ld justice goes forth perverted.
The Lord’s Answer
“Look*pn among the nations, and see; wonder*ld and be astounded. For*ln I am doing a work in your days that*ld you would not believe if told.
For*ln behold, I am raising up the Chaldeans, that*ld bitter and hasty nation, who*ln march through the breadth of the earth, to*ld seize dwellings not their own.
They*ln are dreaded and fearsome; their*ld justice and dignity go forth from themselves.
Their*ln horses are swifter than leopards, more*ld fierce than the evening wolves; their*ld horsemen press proudly on. Their*ln horsemen come from afar; they*ld fly like an eagle swift to devour.
They*ln all come for violence, all*ld their faces forward. They*ld gather captives like sand.
At*ln kings they scoff, and*ld at rulers they laugh. They*ln laugh at every fortress, for*ld they pile up earth and take it.
Then*ln they sweep by like the wind and go on, guilty*ld men, whose own might is their god!”
Habakkuk’s Second Complaint
Are*pn you not from everlasting, O*ld Lord*s my God, my Holy One? We*ld shall not die. O*ln Lord,*s you have ordained them as a judgment, and*ld you, O Rock, have established them for reproof.
You*ln who are of purer eyes than to see evil and*ld cannot look at wrong, why*ln do you idly look at traitors and*ld remain silent when the wicked swallows up the*ld man more righteous than he?
You*ln make mankind like the fish of the sea, like*ld crawling things that have no ruler.
He*ln brings all of them up with a hook; he*ld drags them out with his net; he*ln gathers them in his dragnet; so*ld he rejoices and is glad.
Therefore*ln he sacrifices to his net and*ld makes offerings to his dragnet; for*ln by them he lives in luxury, and*ld his food is rich.
Is*ln he then to keep on emptying his net and*ld mercilessly killing nations forever?
Habakkuk 2
I*pn will take my stand at my watchpost and*ld station myself on the tower, and*ln look out to see what he will say to me, and*ld what I will answer concerning my complaint.
The Righteous Shall Live by His Faith
And*p the Lord*s answered me: “Write*pn the vision; make*ld it plain on tablets, so*ld he may run who reads it.
For*ln still the vision awaits its appointed time; it*ld hastens to the end— it will not lie. If*ln it seems slow, wait for it; it*ld will surely come; it will not delay.
“Behold,*pn his soul is puffed up; it is not upright within him, but*ld the righteous shall live by his faith.

“Moreover,*pn wine is a traitor, an*ld arrogant man who is never at rest. His*ln greed is as wide as Sheol; like*ld death he has never enough. He*ln gathers for himself all nations and*ld collects as his own all peoples.”
Woe to the Chaldeans

Shall*p not all these take up their taunt against him, with scoffing and riddles for him, and say, “Woe*pn to him who heaps up what is not his own— for*ld how long?— and*ld loads himself with pledges!”
Will*ln not your debtors suddenly arise, and*ld those awake who will make you tremble? Then*ld you will be spoil for them.
Because*ln you have plundered many nations, all*ld the remnant of the peoples shall plunder you, for*ln the blood of man and violence to the earth, to*ld cities and all who dwell in them.
“Woe*pn to him who gets evil gain for his house, to*ld set his nest on high, to*ld be safe from the reach of harm!
You*ln have devised shame for your house by*ld cutting off many peoples; you*ld have forfeited your life.
For*ln the stone will cry out from the wall, and*ld the beam from the woodwork respond.
“Woe*pn to him who builds a town with blood and*ld founds a city on iniquity!
Behold,*ln is it not from the Lord*s of hosts that*ld peoples labor merely for fire, and*ld nations weary themselves for nothing?
For*ln the earth will be filled with*ld the knowledge of the glory of the Lord*s as*ld the waters cover the sea.
“Woe*pn to him who makes his neighbors drink— you*ld pour out your wrath and make them drunk, in*ld order to gaze at their nakedness!

You*ln will have your fill of shame instead of glory. Drink,*ld yourself, and show your uncircumcision! The*ln cup in the Lord’s*s right hand will*ld come around to you, and*ld utter shame will come upon your glory!

The*ln violence done to Lebanon will overwhelm you, as*ld will the destruction of the beasts that terrified them, for*ln the blood of man and violence to the earth, to*ld cities and all who dwell in them.
“What*pn profit is an idol when*ld its maker has shaped it, a*ld metal image, a teacher of lies? For*ln its maker trusts in his own creation when*ld he makes speechless idols!
Woe*ln to him who says to a wooden thing, Awake; to*ld a silent stone, Arise! Can*ln this teach? Behold,*ln it is overlaid with gold and silver, and*ld there is no breath at all in it.
But*ln the Lord*s is in his holy temple; let*ld all the earth keep silence before him.”
Habakkuk 3
Habakkuk’s Prayer
A*p prayer of Habakkuk the prophet, according to Shigionoth.
O*pn Lord,*s I have heard the report of you, and*ld your work, O Lord,*s do I fear. In*ln the midst of the years revive it; in*ld the midst of the years make it known; in*ld wrath remember mercy.
God*ln came from Teman, and*ld the Holy One from Mount Paran. Selah*ig His*ln splendor covered the heavens, and*ld the earth was full of his praise.
His*ln brightness was like the light; rays*ld flashed from his hand; and*ld there he veiled his power.
Before*ln him went pestilence, and*ld plague followed at his heels.
He*ln stood and measured the earth; he*ld looked and shook the nations; then*ln the eternal mountains were scattered; the*ld everlasting hills sank low. His*ld were the everlasting ways.
I*ln saw the tents of Cushan in affliction; the*ld curtains of the land of Midian did tremble.
Was*ln your wrath against the rivers, O Lord?*s Was*ld your anger against the rivers, or*ld your indignation against the sea, when*ln you rode on your horses, on*ld your chariot of salvation?
You*ln stripped the sheath from your bow, calling*ld for many arrows. Selah*ig You*ld split the earth with rivers.
The*ln mountains saw you and writhed; the*ld raging waters swept on; the*ln deep gave forth its voice; it*ld lifted its hands on high.
The*ln sun and moon stood still in their place at*ld the light of your arrows as they sped, at*ld the flash of your glittering spear.
You*ln marched through the earth in fury; you*ld threshed the nations in anger.
You*ln went out for the salvation of your people, for*ld the salvation of your anointed. You*ln crushed the head of the house of the wicked, laying*ld him bare from thigh to neck. Selah*ig
You*ln pierced with his own arrows the heads of his warriors, who*ld came like a whirlwind to scatter me, rejoicing*ld as if to devour the poor in secret.
You*ln trampled the sea with your horses, the*ld surging of mighty waters.

I*pn hear, and my body trembles; my*ld lips quiver at the sound; rottenness*ln enters into my bones; my*ld legs tremble beneath me. Yet*ln I will quietly wait for the day of trouble to*ld come upon people who invade us.
Habakkuk Rejoices in the Lord

Though*pn the fig tree should not blossom, nor*ld fruit be on the vines, the*ln produce of the olive fail and*ld the fields yield no food, the*ln flock be cut off from the fold and*ld there be no herd in the stalls,
yet*ln I will rejoice in the Lord;*s I*ld will take joy in the God of my salvation.
God,*sln the Lord, is my strength; he*ld makes my feet like the deer’s; he*ld makes me tread on my high places. To*pn the choirmaster: with stringed instruments.
